species.taxonomic_comments: Subgenus: Bombus.

Subgenus: Subterraneobombus. A predominantly yellow color form found near Corvallis and Ashland, Oregon, is believed to be this species, but there have been no molecular assessments to confirm this (Williams et al. 2011).
Subgenus: Pyrobombus.

This species was previously thought to be a synonym or subspecies of B. vagans, but treated as a valid taxon by Yanega (2013). According to Williams et al. (2014), it has not been possible to obtain DNA barcodes of B. cockerelli from which to assess whether it is conspecific. However, despite its taxonomic uncertainty, we recognize B. cockerelli following Yanega (2013) and ITIS (2008).
Subgenus: Cullumanobombus.

Subgenus: Thoracobombus. This is the record for the broader concept of Bombus fervidus, which includes B. californicus. This is the treatment accepted by Williams et al (2014) and is followed by NatureServe.

Bombus californicus was considered to be conspecific with Bombus fervidus by Williams et al. (2014), but recognized as distinct by others (e.g., Ascher and Pickering 2020, Wright et al. 2017). Morphologically, the two are nearly indistinguishable (Koch et al 2018) and DNA barcodes show little divergence between western (californicus) and eastern (fervidus) specimens (Williams et al. 2014). Others have noted that there are distinct ecological differences between B. californicus and B. fervidus where the two are sympatric (Hobbs 1966, Thorp et al. 1983, Wright et al. 2017).

Koch et al. (2018) conducted phylogenetic and population genetic analyses that confirmed two well-supported lineages. In areas where the species are sympatric, they appear to be phenotypically divergent and may occupy different habitats. However, the authors note that despite this evidence, it is not possible to assign valid names to either lineage, because both include the color phenotypes found in the original species descriptions of B. fervidus and B. californicus.
Subgenus: Bombus. Previously treated as conspecific with B. occidentalis by Milliron (1971).
Subgenus: Cullumanobombus.
Subgenus: Psithyrus.

Subgenus Alpinobombus. B. kluanensis was split from B. neoboreus by Williams and Cannings (2016). Studies have demonstrated that members of Alpinobombus may not always be identifiable with morphological characters alone (Williams et al. 2012; 2015), and taxonomy is in flux, as cryptic species have been described (e.g., B. kluanensis) on the basis of molecular data (Williams et al. 2016).
Subgenus: Cullumanobombus.

Subgenus Alpinobombus. Bombus natvigi was split from B. hyperboreus by Williams et al. (2015). North American and Greenland records are now B. natvigi and B. hyperboreus is restricted to Europe and Asia. Studies have demonstrated that members of Alpinobombus may not always be identifiable with morphological characters alone (Williams et al. 2012; 2015), and taxonomy is in flux, as cryptic species have been described (e.g., B. kluanensis in 2016) on the basis of molecular data (Williams et al. 2016).

Subgenus: Alpinobombus. B. kluanensis was split from B. neoboreus by Williams and Cannings (2016). Studies have demonstrated that members of Alpinobombus may not always be identifiable with morphological characters alone (Williams et al. 2012; 2015), and taxonomy is in flux, as cryptic species have been described (e.g., B. kluanensis in 2016) on the basis of molecular data (Williams et al. 2016).

Williams (2021) elevates Bombus occidentalis mckayi (= B. mckayi) and B. occidentalis occidentalis (= B. occidentalis sensu stricto) to full species level. Includes the taxon proximus, described previously as a separate species (Williams et al. 2012).

Subgenus: Thoracobombus. Bombus sonorus and B. pensylvanicus are considered conspecific (Williams et al. 2014). A population from the south of Mexico (state of Chiapas) is morphologically and genetically distinct from the rest of North America, and could be a separate undescribed species. Further sampling is needed to clarify the situation (Hatfield et al. 2015).

Subgenus: Alpinobombus. Williams et al. (2015) split B. polaris from B. pyrrhopygus; populations in Europe and Asia are considered B. pyrrhopygus, and B. polaris is restricted to North America and Greenland. Studies have demonstrated that members of Alpinobombus may not always be identifiable with morphological characters alone (Williams et al. 2012; 2015), and taxonomy is in flux, as cryptic species have been described (e.g., B. kluanensis in 2016) on the basis of molecular data (Williams et al. 2016).
Subgenus: Psithyrus.

Subgenus: Bombus. B. occidentalis was previously considered to be conspecific with B. terricola (e.g. Williams 2008, Milliron 1971). A large-scale mitochondrial DNA analysis by Williams et al. (2012) supports B. occidentalis as a species separate from B. terricola.

Subgenus: Psithyrus.

Williams (1998, 2018) and Williams et al. (2014) consider that Bombus intrudens, B. variabilis, B. sololensis, B. guatemalensis, and B. mysticus might be one species based on morphological evidence. Williams et al. (2014) use the more commonly used name B. variabilis for the North American populations, while Williams (2018) uses the oldest available name B. intrudens for the broader concept. Williams states that in the interest of stability, it might be best to retain 'variabilis', even if 'intrudens' is the oldest and thus the valid taxonomic name for the whole species as we currently understand it.
Given the similarity of this species to A. estebana, Orr determinations of the latter species from before 2015 should be checked against A. chihuahua if from east of Arizona (Orr 2018).

The subgenus Anthophora (Micranthophora) was previously synonymized with Anthophora (Heliophila) but morphological and multi-gene molecular phylogenetic evidence by Orr (2018) confirm it as a subgenus, and they formally reject the synonymy of A. (Micranthophora) to A. (Heliophila).

The subgenus Anthophora (Micranthophora) was previously synonymized with Anthophora (Heliophila) but morphological and multi-gene molecular phylogenetic evidence by Orr (2018) confirm it as a subgenus, and they formally reject the synonymy of A. (Micranthophora) to A. (Heliophila).

The subgenus Anthophora (Micranthophora) was previously synonymized with Anthophora (Heliophila) but morphological and multi-gene molecular phylogenetic evidence by Orr (2018) confirm it as a subgenus, and they formally reject the synonymy of A. (Micranthophora) to A. (Heliophila).

Anthophora flavocincta is a nomen novum for A. nigrocincta Provancher, 1895 because that was a primary junior homonym of A. nigrocincta LePeletier, 1841 (Sheffield and Perron 2014).

The subgenus Anthophora (Micranthophora) was previously synonymized with Anthophora (Heliophila) but morphological and multi-gene molecular phylogenetic evidence by Orr (2018) confirm it as a subgenus, and they formally reject the synonymy of A. (Micranthophora) to A. (Heliophila).
Subgenus Paramegilla.

The subgenus Anthophora (Micranthophora) was previously synonymized with Anthophora (Heliophila) but morphological and multi-gene molecular phylogenetic evidence by Orr (2018) confirm it as a subgenus, and they formally reject the synonymy of A. (Micranthophora) to A. (Heliophila).

The subgenus Anthophora (Micranthophora) was previously synonymized with Anthophora (Heliophila) but morphological and multi-gene molecular phylogenetic evidence by Orr (2018) confirm it as a subgenus, and they formally reject the synonymy of A. (Micranthophora) to A. (Heliophila).

The subgenus Anthophora (Micranthophora) was previously synonymized with Anthophora (Heliophila) but morphological and multi-gene molecular phylogenetic evidence by Orr (2018) confirm it as a subgenus, and they formally reject the synonymy of A. (Micranthophora) to A. (Heliophila).
Subgenus Anthophoroides.

The subgenus Anthophora (Micranthophora) was previously synonymized with Anthophora (Heliophila) but morphological and multi-gene molecular phylogenetic evidence by Orr (2018) confirm it as a subgenus, and they formally reject the synonymy of A. (Micranthophora) to A. (Heliophila).
Subgenus Anthophoroides.
Described as Emphoropsis excellens.
May include H. murihirta (M. Orr, pers. comm, 2019).
Described as Emphoropsis infernalis tristissima. May include H. salviae (M. Orr, pers. comm, 2019).
This is closely related to and could be confused with the recently (2013) named M. chomskyi.
Based on molecular analysis, Sheffield et al. (2011) considered Megachile laurita, M. semilaurita, and M. alamosana to be melanistic forms of M. anograe and synonymized them.
Sheffield and Westby (2007) note that Megachile hilata is known from only one sex (female) and suggest M. bruneri as a possible synonym.
Sheffield and Westby (2007) note that Megachile hookeri is known from only one sex (female) and suggest M. nevadensis as a possible synonym.
Mitchell (1936) redescribed this species based on the type specimen, but noted the possibility that it is an "abnormal specimen of one of the other species of Xanthosarus."
In his description, Mitchell (1937) notes its similarity to Megachile mojavensis.
Originally placed in the subgenus Xeromegachile, but Michener (2000) synonymized both Xeromegachile and Derotropis with the subgenus Megachiloides.
Megachile prosopidis was previously synonymized with M. occidentalis but was resurrected by Snelling (1990).
See Sheffield (2013) for an updated key to the species in the oenotherae species group.
In his description, Mitchell (1936) notes the similarity of this species to Megachile integra.
Previously considered a subspecies of Megachile mendica; elevated to species status by Bzdyk (2012).
Sheffield (2013) provides an updated key to the to the oenotherae species group of the subgenus Megachiloides.
Rightmeyer et al (2013) conclude that Osmia francisconis, which would otherwise be historic, is a synonym.

Mitchell (1962) and Krombein et al. (1979) placed O. felti in the subgenus Monilosmia, while Sandhouse (1939), who revised the Nearctic species, placed it in the subgenus Nothosmia. Both Monilosmia and Nothosmia are included in Melanosmia by Michener (2000).
Placed in subgenus Chenosmia by Krombein et al. (1979). Michener (2000) included Centrosmia, Chenosmia, Monilosmia, and Nothosmia in Melanosmia. Resembles O. ribifloris.
One of few species of traditional subgenus Acanthosmioides in the US, although Rightmyer et al. (2013) do not recognize this subgenus as valid.

Gibbs et al. (2017) removed Osmia subarctica from synonymy with O. tersula based on an a close examination of the holotype and other specimens of both species. In addition, they synonymize Osmia michiganensis with O. subarctica; O. michiganenis was described based on a single male specimen.

species.common_name: San Francisco Bay Area Leafcutter Bee

species.taxonomic_comments: Perdita glamis placed in synonymy with P. stephanomeriae because an examination of the holotype of P. glamis showed that it clearly matched P. stephanomeriae Portman and Griswold (2017).
Prosopis (= Hylaeus) nilotica is a replacement name for Nesoprosopis obscurata Perkins, a junior homonym of Prosopis obscurata Schenck (Daly and Magnacca 2003).
Blackburn used both Prosopis satellus and P. satelles. Perkins (1899), as first reviser, used satelles (Daly and Magnacca 2003).
